div.p:
You have reason to think me the most
ungrateful of beings - Yet from your
benevolent indulgence I feel assured
that you do not condemn me utterly
unheard - I received your last kind
letter dated Novr.November 1st first 43 many
months ago - but I did not receive
the books Turnbulls life and the Nos.Numbers
of the Journal of Science for some time
afterwards - I was in London with
my sister Mrs. Lestock Wilson; staying
the winter and spring of the ensuing
year with her and being in a whirl-
-windwhirlwind or a whirlpool all the time I
was in Town I absolutely had not
an hour or half an hour in which
I could write a rational letter - The
answers to notes of invitation and
letters home and visit and the necessity
of eating drinking and sleeping absolutely
took up every moment - Then I was
travelling to various places in the country
in England and I did not reach home
till May (5th) I found your books and
and was going to write to you
when I was taken ill - with Eresipelas

I forgot to tell you that I had a very
serious illness the year before as the
newspaper truly informed you -
But The Eresipelas which I had in May last though not so dan-
gerousdangerous as the previous attack in 43 was
alarming enough my pulse being above
100 considerably - Providentially however
by good nursing and care & skill of a
good physician (Sir Henry Marsh of Dublin
I was recovered - One of my sisters nursed me One
who never had the pleasure of your
acquaintance & whose name Harriet
Butler wife of the Revd Richard Butler
of Trim may perhaps never have reached
you - The most amiable and the
most highly informed among our
sex are often those whose names are
unknown to fame.

But instead of writing you this
eulogy on my dear sister Harriet I
had better finish my own exculpation
I have only to add that I was so long
after this illness forbidden the use
of my pen and I am but just now
permitted the free use of it - free use
I can hardly yet say - for I am often called
upon before I have been half an hour
with pen in hand called upon by my
guardian angels desiring me to lay
it down and not to tire myself to death
- My friends are really too careful of
me - but I am not killed with kindness
I am only vexed that I cannot write to
thank my absent and distant friends
for favors - I have never since my illness written one
line yet of what I had begun to write
before - I have written only letters and
scarcely any letters except to my own family
or the particular friends in London
who were urgent for replies to their
inquiries about my health -
Joanna Baillie and Mrs. Marcet for
instance and Dr. Hollands wife
Sidney Smith's daughter

Must I name Sidney Smith to an
American? Yes surely as you are not
one of the Repudiators you probably
are not offended by the truth or by
the wit and humor of his remarks

I saw something of him and behind
the scenes, as I may say, during my visit
to London - I saw him at his daughters
quite at his ease - not playing Wit
and then he was peculiarly agreeable
I think him a very amiable affection
ateaffectionate and truly benevolent man
And at his own residence, Coomb FlowryCombe Florey & in his own
parish he is I am assured quite adored

And the person who last told me so
was one worthy of credit and one able
to judge herself a most amiable woman
Lady Bell - widow of the celebrated Sir
Charles Bell the Surgeon - whose man are just re-
embarked by her
May Read than

I think you are too severe upon
(Coll Turnbulls Memoirs - M.rs. Edgeworth and
I have found many parts of them very
4
interesting - all those parts of his personal
narratives in London & Paris, and
every where when he describes dramatic
ally and from the life truly and exactly
what he saw and heard of the various
characters he met with - especially in
revolutionary France - The facts are always
interesting to human creatures & as part
of the history of human nature Facts that
illustrate the characters of celebrated indiv
-dualsindividuals are always valuable & valued

Even the most trivial words and actions
for instance of such persons as Talleyrand
Madame de Staël Duvret &c - long posterity will
read with curiosity while all the long letters
and pious justifi touching only by gone
politics or private intrigues of diplomatists are
useless & tiresome and the exercise of the books there
remain unread even by the present generation &
may prevent by the size & weight how much they
Twill the volume prevent its going to posterity
- The beautiful sketches with which the book
is ornamented will do much however to preserve
it in the houses and libraries of every person of any
taste for the Arts -
Thank you my dear Sir for sending me the
Book which has amused me more than I
could have expected when first I saw its bulk
& felt its weight - Your American books
are in general heavier than ours of the same sizes
probably from the paper being the - you print
beautifully when you chuse so to do - And most
shabbily & on vile paper when are only looking to
cheapness & supplying the amusement of the day & hours

I have An American copy of Helen which is on
the worst paper conceivable & squeezed into the smallest
compass and worst type - But still I am thankful
that the Americans republished it at all -

You ask me about a forthcoming novel
There is no Forthcoming Novel by Maria E - I am writing a tale
but I have been so interrupted by illness - London - &c &c &c
I know not whether it will ever be finished -
of which you say the newspaper assure - I believe
that paragraph must have been put in to newspaper
by Bentley who has just republished in one volume
my father's memoirs which I have cut down to
one volume, by taking out all that I thought su-
perfluoussuperfluous in the volume which I wrote - I have not
touched my fathers part - Exactly upon the principle
which I suggested wdwould be advantageous to Coll Turnbull
5
Memoirs, I left in my fathers all that was person
alpersonal narrative and which I felt was interesting
and had been assured the public so found -

Bentley was not anxious to publish my abridg-
mentabridgement of these Memoirs fearing there would not be
demand for them at the present day - and
he made an effort to engage me to promise
him "a forthcoming novel" were his very words
which he understood he said I was writing

I told him that I had no novel ready to
come out and that I never bargained for any
work till it was completed - and that I would
not enter into any engagement for what I am
writing or bind myself in any way to finish
it or to give it to him - But that when finished
I would give him the first offer of the book or
that if I die & consent to be published my execu
torexecutor should give him the first offer - I have
bored you with this long story because you
have persuaded me that you are so much
interested for me and all my doings, and works
that I felt irresistibly tempted to bore you
through and through -

I send you a huge packet of auto
graphsautographs which I hope will cost you nothing
else they will cost you more than they
are worth - At your suggestion I have sent
you some papers (de trop) of the story which
I am now writing and while I had
- I have now cut the pages into slips for
your convenience of giving away to your
autograph lovers - and I have written my
name and the date of the year at the bottom
of each for I was anxious to do whatever you
wish in this small matter - the only opportu
nityopportunity I have for of shewing my sense of your
continued attentions and really valuable
gifts to me (and among the most valuable I count yryour
time in writing to me - You who have
so much of correspondence to do for so many
Your account of the Associations of Young
Men for mutual improvement is highly
creditable to your part of the country and
will no doubt operate happily upon literary society
and on moral conduct in the succeeding
6 generations - I heard much of "Young England" when I was in London - I do not know how to explain or define to you what is meant by young England - Mr. Milne a young fashionable & poet in London - a diner out And a speaker in parliament who has obtained early celebrity or at least notoriety in all these lines of life is at the head or thinks himself at the head of Young England - They profess to be moral, religious, honorable and chivalrous - not to be utilitarians (those are their particular detastation - Not to be high Churchmen - quite - but to support Church & State - not to be P ites - - quite - but to be liberal & not too liberal to P liberal to Catholics also - but to Catholics If they could keep their enthusiasm & conduct up to the high tone of morality they profess and if they could stand steady on the broad stone of honor without antics or bravadoing & if they could keep clear of party spirit, affectation & puppyism they would do a wonderful deal of good & would deserve the highest honors of their country - But here are many ifs, and difficulties which not one said of "Young England - it is" ever thought of when they adopted the apella- -tion and above all), - the dress -. How would you Young England know England
Why by his open breast or open shirt collar
-collar to this says in truth he must have none - but
his shirt must turn down at the neck which school boys or I am told, in imitation of the ancient Romans (who had no shirts) - If the gentle man does not chuse to bare his neck and shews himself like Lord Byrons picture if he will wear a neck kerchief cravat or
7 by whatever name it should be called it must be white - "Down with Black Collars" as it was cried by the Paris mob to your Coll. Turnbull in 97 - when he ran from them & wisely tore off his coat & burned it rather than be mobbed - Benites the white neck cloth or bare neck Young England is to be known by his long hair streaming over his face and shoulders - curled or uncurled - Black Brown or Red so it must be worn - natural or false so it must be or you cannot be a young England - much of their strength is in their hair - But I am writing upon them much more of my paper than I can afford I am sorry to hear of burglaries in your city - In spite of your intellectual improvements - How is this? Does moral conduct not follow from intellectual cultivation The subject question interests me much - The object of the tale I am now writing or thinking of writing is to shew that those who attempt to improve the education and condition of the poor ( we have poor in our country) or of the lower classes in any country must take special care that the moral education keeps pace with the intellectual else they do more good than harm to society and do not increase the real happiness of the individuals - my heroine is to be raised from Town life - and the benevolent lady gives her all manner of accomplishments but forgets principles and does not prepare her temper for the trials she must meet with in her sudden rise in life - nor does she teach her the self-control whicn in her motherless state is peculiarly necessary to enable her to resist the temptations to which a young beauty parvenue is exposed - As far as concerns my heroine & her patroness only you cannot except for my sake my dear Sir be much interested in all this - But perhaps your daughter or Mrs Sprague may & may have heard of facts and
8 examples that would be useful to me to know - I mean in the course of the story (if I can to shew that unless great precautions are taken in the preparation of the individual raised per saltem in life, there is a bad chance of the rise in condition being for their happiness I shall touch upon the cure that ought to be taken by patrons & patronesses of charita ble schools both to keep the moral ed.n equal to the intellectual and also to make the motives for industry and for the acquirement of knowledge, pure and good - not connected with envy as emulation is to apt to be - and not merely springing from avarice or worldly ambition - Those motives are subject to great disappointments & to lead at all times to heart burnings if nothing worse and to unhappiness within if not in out- ward circumstances or appearances. My I was called away as I was writing this to go to see a show on the Green at the end of the village - a show of Elephant & horses and horseman ship - and Mrs. E whom you know, and another Mrs. E whom you dont know, my brother Francis's wife, a Spanish lady who not who has now five children who form the whole family at Edgeworths town & all went to see the show - The children all have the hooping cough but the entertainment operated so powerfully that they never once hooped during the hour we were there - I was never better entertained tho I have seen fine exhibitions of horsemanship in Dublin & London - I was surprised to see in the first place the size & magnificence of the Tent - One hundred & forty feet circumference! Seats all round the circus raised four rows & covered with painted cloth like carpets We saw two a most graceful and active youth ride two horses abreast - one foot on one the other foot on the other horse round & round the center pole of the tent - then four in hand - Then two young men full canter - One standing on the others shoulder! & waiving hands & arms A large village audience had assembled and among those of the upper classwere the protestant clergyman &
clergyman & his sister who went with us - and the Catholic priest - I was very glad to see them both sitting on the same bench and enjoying & sanctioning these innocent diversions - Several pretty young girls were there and I am sure enjoyed as much real pleasure as if they had been finely dressed and raised from their rank humble stations to be young ladies in high life & sitting at a grand theatre in London - perhaps envious or jealous of the dress or beauty or high birth of somebody opposite to them or in the same box - The elephant was as good at Edgeworths town as in London and ran his rational recreations over as well as if he were exhibiting at the Tower or the Zoological Gardens - And now my dear Dr. Sprague I think you will say I have written enough and very glad shall I be if you think that I have made up for long silence & ingratitude
div.closer: I really am your grateful and much obliged Maria Edgeworth

postscript.p: I continue to find Sillimans journal a most interesting book - Doctor Robinson professor of astronomy and Astronomer Royal, Armagh and one of our first men of science and of genius much admires this American Journal & I have the pleasure of lending it to him - He is married to my sister Lucy - married her last year - a marriage in which all her family rejoiced - she had been for years in bad health confined by a spine complaint - which she bore with exemplary fortitude & sweet patience - She is now in the enjoyment of as perfect happiness and health as can be - I have said nothing of the books we have been reading - I should have told you that we have been reading Prescott Conquest of Mexico - the most interesting book I have seen this century - I am now hearing it read for the second time - I read it during my convalescence & immediately on my return home found my brother is reading it & I Sharing it over again with the greatest delight
